newsitem.title: NEW ZEALAND: NZ's National Bank lifts floating rate to 10.4 pct.
newsitem.headline: NZ's National Bank lifts floating rate to 10.4 pct.

text.p: The National Bank of New Zealand said on Wednesday it had lifted its floating home lending rate to 10.4 percent from 8.95 percent, joining the bulk of lenders at or near that higher level.
In a statement the bank said the rise was effective from August 11 for new business and for existing borrowers from August 27.
"We have been reviewing our rates over the past six weeks and held off increasing the floating rate as long as we could," retail banking director Bruce Dick said.
"We were hoping to see a decline in wholesale interest rates back to historical levels to avoid any need to impact on customers. Regrettably that has not occurred," he added.
The benchmark money market bank bill rate, the 90-day, is currently at 8.20 percent and has been well above 8.00 percent for several weeks after a sharp jump up from nearer 7.00 percent in late June.
